title: 109_hr5000
content: The Act is titled the "9/11 Commission Civil Liberties Board Act" and includes findings. The "9/11 Commission Civil Liberties Board Act" was created in response to the recommendations made by the National Commission on Terrorist Attacks, including the establishment of a board within the executive branch to oversee civil liberties protections. The National Intelligence Reform Act of 2004 created a civil liberties board lacking necessary authority. The 9/11 Commission recommended establishing a Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board, noting insufficient urgency and funding. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board faced funding challenges, with $750,000 allocated in the President's budget for fiscal year 2006 but no funding line in the budget for fiscal year 2007. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board is to become an independent agency within the Executive branch, and all members must be confirmed by the Senate. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board is composed of a full-time chairman and 4 members appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members are selected based on professional qualifications, achievements, civil liberties expertise, and without regard to political affiliation. No more than 3 members can be from the same political party. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board members are appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members cannot hold incompatible offices in the federal government while serving on the Board. Each member serves a six-year term, with exceptions for filling partial terms and continuing until a successor is appointed. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board members are appointed by the President with Senate approval. Members serve terms of two, three, four, five, and six years from the effective date of the Act. The Board shall meet upon the call of the chairman or a majority of its members. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board members are appointed by the President with Senate approval and serve varying terms. The Board requires three members to constitute a quorum for meetings. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board has the power to issue subpoenas. Section 1061(d) of the Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to allow the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board to issue subpoenas for relevant information from individuals or entities outside the executive branch. Failure to comply with a subpoena may result in enforcement by the United States district court. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board can issue subpoenas to individuals or entities outside the executive branch to produce required evidence. SEC. 6. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Board's duties include receiving and reviewing reports from privacy and civil liberties officers, submitting reports to Congress semiannually. The Board submits reports to Congress semiannually, including unclassified reports to relevant committees and the President, with a classified annex when necessary. At least 2 reports each year must include specific contents. The Board submits semiannual reports to Congress and the President, including activities, findings, recommendations, minority views, and reviewed proposals. The Board submits semiannual reports to Congress and the President, including activities, findings, recommendations, minority views, and reviewed proposals. The Board informs the public by making reports available and holding public hearings. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to include provisions for Privacy and Civil Liberties Officers to ensure protection of classified information and compliance with applicable laws. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to include provisions for Privacy and Civil Liberties Officers to ensure protection of classified information and compliance with applicable laws. SEC. 1062 addresses the establishment of these officers. The Intelligence Reform and Terrorism Prevention Act of 2004 is amended to include provisions for Privacy and Civil Liberties Officers from various government departments to consider privacy and civil liberties concerns when proposing actions. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Officers are tasked with ensuring that government departments consider privacy and civil liberties concerns in their actions, investigate complaints, and provide advice on proposals to retain or enhance privacy rights. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Officers advise on proposals to retain or enhance governmental powers, ensuring a balance between security and privacy rights. They consider supervision, guidelines, and oversight to confine the use of such powers. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Officers, designated by the Board, perform functions related to privacy and civil liberties in departments or agencies. They report directly to department heads and coordinate with the Inspector General to avoid duplication of efforts. The head of each department, agency, or element ensures that privacy and civil liberties officers have necessary resources, are informed of policy changes, consulted by decision-makers, and have access to material and personnel. No reprisal is allowed for making complaints or disclosing information to these officers or the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board must be informed of any possible privacy or civil liberties violations in government anti-terrorism efforts. Federal employees must report such issues, with periodic reports submitted to Congress. The Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board must be informed of any privacy or civil liberties violations in government anti-terrorism efforts. Reports must be submitted to various Congressional committees in unclassified form, with a classified annex if necessary. Each privacy officer and civil liberties officer must submit reports detailing their functions, including reviews, advice given, complaints received, and their dispositions. They are also required to inform the public by making these reports available. The civil liberties officer must make reports available to the public while protecting classified information and comply with human research subject protections. This section does not override other privacy or civil liberties officers' authorities provided by law. In part 46 of title 45, Code of Federal Regulations, regulations are outlined for research conducted or supported by the Department. The amendment adds a new paragraph to Section 1105(a) of title 31, United States Code, requiring a separate statement of appropriations requested for the Privacy and Civil Liberties Oversight Board.
